blurb.body-accessibility: Every effort has been made to make the WOUDC data archive as accessible as possible. If you have any questions, comments, or suggestions on improving data access, please {contact-us}.
blurb.body-intro: Access to the WOUDC data archive is available via numerous mechanisms in support of vendor neutral, multi-application access and integration. Whether you are using the website, geospatial tools or custom solutions, the WOUDC data archive provides flexible, authoritative data access.

csw.blurb: The {ogc-cs} provides a common interface to discover, browse and query discovery metadata (data about data). The WOUDC CSW provides a yellow pages catalogue of all WOUDC data available in the archive. Metadata records are formatted using the ISO 19115/19139 geospatial metadata standards.

note.body: WOUDC provides OGC CSW (version 2.0.2) at the following endpoint: {link}
note.title: WOUDC OGC CSW

csw.title: Catalogue Service for the Web (CSW)

definitions.blurb: Web Services are modelled and managed using a data taxonomy. An RDF-based definitions service exists to describe WOUDC's data taxonomy and relationships.

note.body: WOUDC provides RDF/SKOS at the following endpoint: {link}
note.title: WOUDC Definitions Service

definitions.title: Definitions Service

examples.blurb: The following {github} examples provide high level access and workflow examples of integrating WOUDC Web Services:

links.notebooks: A collection of data centre workflows implemented as IPython notebooks
links.pywoudc: High level package providing Pythonic access to WMO WOUDC data services

examples.title: Examples

iso.blurb-howto: Please consult the {how-to} for detailed information.
iso.blurb-intro: Codelists are managed using the ISO 19115 standard. An ISO 19115 codelist catalogue exists to describe various WOUDC's domain objects for use in metadata.

note.body: WOUDC provides the ISO Codelist Catalogue at the following endpoint: {link}
note.title: WOUDC Codelist Catalogue

iso.title: ISO Codelist Catalogue

note1.body: All data and metadata are subject to the WOUDC {policy}.
note1.title: Data Policy

note2.body: The data revision dates are available on the {stations-page} for stations that have provided revised data.
note2.title: Data Revisions/Updates

blurb.body-howto: Please consult the {how-to} for detailed information.
blurb.body-intro: Observation data are made available via the {search} page, which allows users to browse and filter the entire archive in a responsive, interactive manner. All data provide a link to download data for offline use in a variety of formats.

search.note: Please note that dataset specific limits are put on bulk data download to maintain quality of service.
search.title: Data Search / Download

blurb.body-intro: In addition to traditional data access mechanisms, WOUDC has made the archive available using geospatial web services adhering to publically available international standards. Web services are systems designed to support machine to machine interaction over a network, and are typically utilized in a client/server computing environment made available through programmatic access, associated tools and applications.
blurb.body-standards: The WOUDC web services adhere to open standards ratified by the {ogc} (OGC), and the {iso} (ISO) which enable interoperability and thus make data easy to discover, access, visualize and integrate. OGC and ISO standards play an important role in {interoperability} as part of the {wis} and are supported by numerous off the shelf open source or commercial tools.

table.title: The following OGC web services are made available for standards-based, dynamic data access:

blurb.body-intro: The {wfs} provides a common interface to access geospatial data. Typical use of WFS includes custom query / raw access to geospatial features. The WOUDC WFS provides archive data in numerous formats, including Extended CSV, KML, CSV, GML, ESRI Shapefile, MapInfo, GeoJSON, and NetCDF.
blurb.body-limits: The WFS has a server side limit of a maximum of 200000 features to ensure quality of service and availability.

note.body: WOUDC provides OGC WFS (versions 1.0.0 - 1.1.0) at the following endpoint: {link}
note.title: WOUDC OGC WFS

wms.blurb: The {wms} provides a common interface to visualize geospatial data layers. Typical use of WMS includes simple visualization in web or desktop GIS applications via web friendly image formats such as PNG or JPEG.

note.body: WOUDC provides OGC WMS (versions 1.1.1 - 1.3.0) at the following endpoint: {link}
note.title: WOUDC OGC WMS

wms.title: Web Map Service (WMS)

wps.blurb: The {wps} provides a common interface to define rules, inputs, outputs for geospatial processing / calculations. Typical use of WPS includes custom processes (buffer, overlay). The WOUDC WPS provides a suite of tools used in support of validation of submissions to the Data Centre.

note.body: WOUDC provides OGC WPS (version 1.0.0) at the following endpoint: {link}
note.title: WOUDC OGC WPS

wps.title: Web Processing Service (WPS)

faq.blurb: Here are the answers to some of the most frequently asked questions about our data centre.

questions.answer: The WOUDC is a public website in support of the WMO Global Atmospheric Watch (GAW) programme. WOUDC data is made publically available on behalf of data contributors. For information on data access and usage, please refer to the {policy} page.
questions.text: Who can access the WOUDC data?

questions.answer: Registered contributors can submit data to the WOUDC via FTP. Visit the {submission} page for all of the details. All new data contributors require a WOUDC account. To become a contributor, please visit the {registration-form}.
Registered contributors can access the WOUDC data archive using the WOUDC website, geospatial tools or custom solutions. Visit the {access} page for all the details.
questions.text: How do I access the WOUDC data archive?

questions.answer: The WOUDC currently manages and provides Ozone and Ultra Violet Radiation data. Please refer to {search} to see all WOUDC datasets. Other products such as maps, graphs and reports are also available on the {products} page.
questions.text: What data can I find in WOUDC?

questions.answer: WOUDC data comes from worldwide contributors consisting of institutions, agencies and organizations. Contributors submit their data to WOUDC, where the data are then archived and made available. Please refer to the {contributors-page}.
questions.text: Where does WOUDC get its data from?

questions.answer: Data is typically updated and made available to users within five business day of receipt by WOUDC. Extended CSV (extCSV) data are processed and made available in near real time.
WOUDC uses information provided by contributors who submit data. The WOUDC is responsible for ensuring that the most recent information provided by the contributors is available to all users.
questions.text: Who is responsible for keeping WOUDC information up-to-date?

questions.answer: Yes. The WOUDC provides raw data through a web accessible folder (WAF) as well as Open Geospatial Consortium web services such as Web Map Service and Web Feature Service, providing dynamic, real-time access of the WOUDC data in numerous formats and encodings. For more information, please refer to the {access} page.
questions.text: Can I use my application to automatically retrieve data from WOUDC and also to upload data to WOUDC?

questions.answer: Yes. The WOUDC web application has been developed using Government of Canada directives on {accessibility} and {usability}, which align with {w3c}
questions.text: Can I use my handheld device to access WOUDC?

faq.title: Frequently Asked Questions

blurb.body-extcsv: The extended CSV (extCSV) is the standard data file format for submission to WOUDC. The {extended} standard for the CSV syntax rules support the provision of comments and multiple data content within individual files. The extCSV provides a simple text-based format for data providers when submitting data to the WOUDC, as well as one of many ways for users to integrate ozone and ultraviolet (UV) radiation data into their database, spreadsheet and workflow analysis. Please refer to the {access} page for more information on WOUDC data discovery, access and visualization.
blurb.body-intro: The WOUDC uses ASCII text file format standard for data submissions in an {extended} (ext) Comma-Separated Value (CSV) format.

examples.blurb: The following examples of extCSV files are based on the observation category (open files in a text editor):
examples.title: Examples: extended Comma-Separated Value

formats.note: The WOUDC does not accept files in binary formats such as MS-Excel or MS-Word.
formats.title: File Formats
formats.description: Describes the file format, structure and content of the WOUDC Standard Data File Format. (extcsv).  Samples of files are also included.

glossary.blurb: Terms related to the data centre, including definitions about network operations centres and words and phrases about the storage, management and the transmission of data.

terms.definition: The WOUDC term for the contributing institute or organization responsible for the data submission to the WOUDC.
The WOUDC abbreviation or short form for the institute or organization name.
Measurements of UV-A, UV-B, or erythemally weighted UV radiation. This is a WOUDC defined data category. Refer to ultraviolet radiation.
An Open Geospatial Consortium (OGC) standard for defining interfaces to discover, browse, and query metadata about geospatial records.
The institute or organization that obtains and submits the observation data to the WOUDC.
The abbreviation for Catalogue Service for the Web.

WOUDC term for type of data. Current data categories for ozone are total column ozone, lidar, ozonesonde, Umkehr and ultraviolet radiation data categories are broadband, multiband and high resolution spectral.
The WOUDC term for the type of observation data collection set. Current WOUDC data classes are ozone and solar ultraviolet radiation.
Refers to the data product. Raw data are Level 0 and considered unchanged. Processed data are Level 1 while spectrally gridded data is Level 2, etc.
Refers to value-added products such as maps, statistical summaries (e.g. daily means), data gridded on wavelengths and bandwidths, time series analysis, etc.
Refers to the frequency of data such as D = daily M = monthly.

Refers to a condensed scientific description of the origin, processing and quality of the data, typically written by the scientist responsible for these data and submitted by the contributing agency (formerly called the Scientific Sponsorship Statement (SSS)).
Data version specified by the submitting agency. These versions have the form major.minor (eg. 3.2).
A unit of measurement of atmospheric ozone columnar density, used as a measure of total column ozone, which is dominated by ozone in the stratospheric ozone layer.
The abbreviation for Data Sponsorship Statement.
The solar erythemal ultraviolet (UV) radiation which is defined by the integral over the UV wavelengths of the irradiance multiplied by the erythemal action spectrum (refer to {carcinogenesis}).

The abbreviation for the extended (ext) Comma-Separated Values (CSV) file format created by WOUDC as a data archive file format standard that supports the provision of comments and multi data content within individual files.
Refer to extCSV.
The WOUDC term for the format of a data file. Data files of a given content will always contain the tables and fields specified by the WOUDC for that form. Refer to the {registration-page}.
The version of the WOUDC extCSV file format (represented by the form index). If the existing file structure is altered the form index will be increased.

The abbreviation for the Global Atmosphere Watch programme of the World Meteorological Organization (WMO). The GAW programme was established in 1991 to provide scientific data on the chemical composition of the atmosphere.
The abbreviation for the station identifier defined by the GAW programme of the WMO. This identifier is a three letter code and is used in the WOUDC extCSV formatted files.
The abbreviation for the GAW station (platform) name.
The abbreviation for the GAW Station Information System.
Refer to GAW.
Height (elevation) in metres above sea level (m.a.s.l.).
The sensor or device used to measure / provide the data.
The manufacturer or make of an instrument or sensor.
The model identifier (ID) where applicable. For example, a typical Brewer spectrophotometer model is MKIII and an ECC sonde is 6A.
The serial number (S/N) for an instrument or sensor.
The common name of the instrument or sensor. For example, the Brewer spectrophotometer is called the "Brewer" where as the Brewer-Mast ozonesonde is called the "Brewer-Mast."
The abbreviation for the International Organization for Standardization.
In signed decimal degrees (DD), with north positive and south negative.
Abbreviated term for Light Detection and Ranging. This is a WOUDC defined category.
The latitude, longitude and height of the data collection; typically the location of the station (platform) and instrument.
In signed decimal degrees (DD), with east positive and west negative.
Data about data. Additional spatial, temporal and instrument information for data within the WOUDC.
Measured with several discrete, pass-band filters with nominal spectral resolution of 2-10 nm at FWHM. This is a WOUDC defined data category. Refer to ultraviolet radiation.
Network for the Detection of Atmospheric Composition Change
The duration, usually one local or two days yielding a single profile.

The abbreviation for the Open Geospatial Consortium which serves as a global forum for the collaboration of geospatial data; they set the international standards and provide services that promote geospatial interoperability.
Refer to OGC.

A special form of oxygen with the chemical formula O3. Ozone in the stratosphere absorbs some of the sun's biologically harmful ultraviolet radiation. Ozone is one of the current WOUDC data classes and includes these data categories: total column ozone (two levels: daily and hourly values), lidar vertical profiles, ozonesonde vertical profiles, and Umkehr (two levels: N-value and C-Umkehr) vertical profiles.
A balloon-borne, ozone instrument used to vertically profile the ozone amount in the atmosphere. This is a WOUDC defined data category. Refer to ozone.
Refer to Station.
Refer to Station Type.
The name of the project (e.g. IONS, EUVB, Antarctica).
Resource Description Framework - A part of the SKOS Web Service standard from World Wide Web Consortium ({w3}).
An update to existing data. This may be a minor adjustment or a major re-write of the data.
The abbreviation for the WMO Scientific Advisory Group. WOUDC receives guidance from the WMO SAG for issues related to both ozone and solar ultraviolet radiation data.
Refer to SAG.
The person responsible for the data quality.
Refer to Data Sponsorship Statement (DSS).
The abbreviation for Southern Hemisphere ADditional Ozonesondes.
The abbreviation and designator for a WOUDC mobile station (platform) for shipborne data. Refer to station (platform) type.
Simple Knowledge Organization System - A part of the Web Service standard from World Wide Web Consortium ({w3}).
The serial number of the instrument. Refer to instrument serial number.
WOUDC's term for the source of the data e.g. NDACC, SHADOZ
Radiation is measured in a continuous spectral band, with a resolution of less than or equal to 2 nm. This is a WOUDC defined data category. Refer to ultraviolet radiation.
The station platform at which an observation is performed. The stations consist of stationary platforms (including towers) and mobile platforms (including ships).
The abbreviation (short form) used to identify whether a station (platform) is stationary (STN) or on a ship (SHP).
The abbreviation and designator for the WOUDC stationary or station (platform) data. Refer to station (platform) type.
The institute or organization, other than the contributor, that technically or financially supports the observation.
Total column ozone measurements. This is a WOUDC defined data category. Refer to ozone and also to Dobson Unit.

Often abbreviated to UV. Short-wave radiation (UV-B) is absorbed by the ozone layer, whereas long-wave UV (UV-A) passes through the ozone layer and reaches the ground. The WOUDC UV radiation data is in the UV-A and UV-B regions (290 to 400 nm) of the E-M spectrum. UV radiation is one of the WOUDC data classes and includes three data categories: broadband, multiband, and high resolution spectral.
For Umkehr measurements using 14 N-values (representing 14 solar zenith angles). This is a WOUDC defined data category. Refer to ozone.

The international abbreviation for Coordinated Universal Time. It is the standard time common to every place in the world. The WMO has adopted the UTC as the standard time for use in reporting all meteorological data.
The signed amount of time subtracted from the local time in order to obtain UTC time (where east is positive and local time is defined by the data originator), represented in ISO-8601 time (hh).
One of the WOUDC Data Classes. Example of WOUDC UV Radiation data are Multiband, Broadband and Spectral.

The abbreviation for the World Data Centres. WOUDC is one of six GAW WDCs that collect, document and archive atmospheric measurements and the associated metadata from stations worldwide and make these data freely available to the scientific community.
The entire archive of contributed data files in Extended CSV format is made available at {waf} for users to browse, download or integrate into their workflows.

A common interface to access geospatial data. Typical use of WFS includes custom query / raw access to geospatial features. The WOUDC WFS provides archive data in numerous formats, including Extended CSV, KML, CSV, GML, ESRI Shapefile, MapInfo, GeoJSON, and NetCDF.
A common interface to visualize geospatial data layers. Typical use of WMS includes simple visualization in web or desktop GIS applications via web friendly image formats such as PNG or JPEG.

The acronym for the WMO Information System which is responsible for the telecommunications and data management functions for weather, climate and water information to ensures adequate uniformity and standardization in the data, information and communications practices procedures and specifications employed among WMO members.
The abbreviation for the World Meteorological Organization. The WMO carries out its work through scientific and technical programmes such as the WOUDC.
Refer to WIS.
Six specific geographic portions of the globe defined by the WMO.
Refer to WDC.
Refer to WMO.
One of six WDCs which are part of the GAW programme of the WMO.
terms.term: World Ozone and Ultraviolet Radiation Data Centre (WOUDC)

terms.definition: The abbreviation for the World Ozone and Ultraviolet Radiation Data Centre.
A number assigned by the WOUDC to uniquely identify each station (platform). Referred to as the WOUDC ID.

glossary.title: Glossary
glossary.description: List of terms specific to the WOUDC archive and data

blurb.body-access: All WOUDC data are made available by using the {search}, or web accessible folder (WAF) access. In addition, the Open Geospatial Consortium web services provide enhanced access to the archive, which provides standards-based-on-demand access to the archive. For more information, please refer to the {access} page.
blurb.body-contributors: There are over 500 registered {stations} in the archive from over 150 {contributors}. Metadata such as station lists with locations, are available from the WOUDC Website.
blurb.body-datasets: Ozone data set categories include total column ozone and vertical profile data from lidar measurements, ozonesonde flights, and the Umkehr technique. Ultraviolet (UV) radiation data set categories include broadband, multiband, and high resolution spectral data types.
blurb.body-intro: The World Ozone and Ultraviolet Radiation Data Centre (WOUDC) is one of six World Data Centres which are part of the Global Atmosphere Watch programme of the World Meteorological Organization. The WOUDC data centre is operated by the Meteorological Service of Canada, a branch of Environment and Climate Change Canada.
blurb.body-products: Value added data products include total ozone time series graphs and near real-time ozone maps.

milestones.1964: first publication of Ozone Data for the World issued
milestones.1992: solar ultraviolet (UV) radiation data is added to the data archives; data centre renamed to World Ozone and Ultraviolet Radiation Data Centre (WOUDC)
milestones.1995: initial website and FTP site created
milestones.2006: first data DVD ROM with complete data archive released
milestones.2015: website updated, providing modernized mechanisms supporting discovery, visualization, access and management of ozone and UV data

policy.blurb: Use of the WOUDC data are governed by the {wmo-policy} and {gaw-policy}.

doi.blurb: WOUDC has registered {dois} for both Ozone and UV data. DOIs are persistent identifiers that allow research data to be accessible and citable. They make research data easier to access, reuse and verify, thereby making it easier to build on previous work, conduct new research and avoid duplicating already existing work.
doi.title: Digital Object Identifiers (DOI)

gaw.blurb: Use of data obtained from one of the WMO GAW World Data Centres (WDC) is subject to the following statement endorsed by the WMO Executive Council and the Commission for Atmospheric Sciences (EC/CAS) panel of experts working group on environmental pollution and atmospheric chemistry [WMO, 2001a].:

note.body: For scientific, educational and policy related use, access to these [GAW] data is unlimited and provided without charge. By their use you accept that an offer of co-authorship will be made through personal contact with the data providers or owners whenever substantial use is made of their data. In all cases, an acknowledgment must be made to the data providers or owners and to the data centre when these data are used within a publication.
note.title: WMO Policy Statement

gaw.title: Global Atmosphere Watch Data Use Policy

policy.gaw-policy: WMO Global Atmosphere Watch (GAW) data use policy

products.blurb: When publishing products extracted from WOUDC such as graphs, lists, maps or metadata you are expected to acknowledge the WOUDC, as the data and produce source, using the appropriate citation, as per the example provided.

note.body: Environment and Climate Change Canada, Toronto (n.d.). World Meteorological Organization-Global Atmosphere Watch Program (WMO-GAW)/World Ozone and Ultraviolet Radiation Data Centre (WOUDC). Retrieved October 24, 2013, from https://woudc.org.
note.title: Example (3): Citation for products originating from the WOUDC site

products.title: Publishing Products

publishing.blurb-citations: When publishing data retrieved from the WOUDC you are expected to acknowledge the contributors who author these data as the data source and the WOUDC, using the appropriate citation as per the example provided.
publishing.blurb-contributors: For a complete list of all contributors refer to the {contributors-page}.

note1.body: JMA, & NASA-WFF. World Meteorological Organization-Global Atmosphere Watch Program (WMO-GAW)/World Ozone and Ultraviolet Radiation Data Centre (WOUDC) [Data]. Retrieved October 24, 2013, from https://woudc.org. doi:10.14287/10000001
note1.title: Example (1): Citation for ozone data originating (contributed) from the Japan Meteorological Agency (JMA) and NASA (NASA-WFF) retrieved from the WOUDC site

items.ozone: WMO/GAW Ozone Monitoring Community, World Meteorological Organization-Global Atmosphere Watch Program (WMO-GAW)/World Ozone and Ultraviolet Radiation Data Centre (WOUDC) [Data]. Retrieved October 24, 2013, from https://woudc.org. A list of all contributors is available on the website. doi:10.14287/10000001
items.uv: WMO/GAW UV Radiation Monitoring Community, World Meteorological Organization-Global Atmosphere Watch Program (WMO-GAW)/World Ozone and Ultraviolet Radiation Data Centre (WOUDC) [Data]. Retrieved October 24, 2013, from https://woudc.org. A list of all contributors is available on the website. doi:10.14287/10000002

note2.title: Example (2): Citation for data originating (contributed) from a large number of organizations retrieved from the WOUDC site

publishing.title: Publishing Data

policy.title: Data Use Policy

blurb.body-intro: The WMO facilitates the free and unrestricted exchange of data and information, products and services in real or near-real time on matters relating to safety and security of society, economic welfare and the protection of the environment.
blurb.body-resolution40: {link} WMO policy and practice for the exchange of meteorological and related data and products including guidelines on the relationships in commercial meteorological activities.

quality.blurb: The WOUDC data are subject to the Global Atmosphere Watch quality assurance system and the oversight of the Scientific Advisory Groups on ozone and solar ultraviolet radiation.

eccc.blurb: The WOUDC is operated by the Department of the Environment (referred to as Environment and Climate Change Canada) and undertakes the following activities:
eccc.item2: Checks submitted data for necessary format elements and the availability of comprehensive metadata and reject the submission of data that do not meet these formal criteria;
eccc.item3: Performs plausibility and consistency checks on submitted data, flag data problems, and provide feedback to the stations, when necessary;
eccc.item4: Provides collection of data user feedback;
eccc.item5: Shares results of quality assessment and user feedback with data contributors so that data can be corrected or corrective actions can be taken as required; and
eccc.title: Environment and Climate Change Canada

quality.gaw-blurb: The primary objectives of the {gaw-qa} are to ensure that the data in the World Data Centres are consistent, of known and adequate quality, supported by comprehensive metadata, and sufficiently complete to describe global atmospheric states with respect to spatial and temporal distribution.

blurb.body-intro: The SAG on ozone and solar ultraviolet radiation establish data quality objectives and {sop} outlining measurement methods and procedures.
blurb.body-standards: The SAG ensure that all data produced by the system conform to international standards, via the following calibration centres:

brewer.text: WMO GAW World Calibration Centre for Brewer total ozone measurements

dobson.text: WMO GAW World Calibration Centre for Dobson total ozone measurements

ozonesonde.text: WMO GAW World Calibration Centre for ozonesonde measurements

quality.title: Data Quality

standards.blurb-howto: More information can be found on the {access} page.
standards.blurb-intro: WOUDC adheres to open standards which enable interoperability (discovery, access, visualization). Standards play an important role in {interoperability} as part of the {wis} and are supported by numerous off the shelf open source or commercial tools.
standards.title: Standards

map-instructions.body-panning: {panning} To pan the map, click and drag over the interactive map. Alternatively, {tab} focus to the interactive map box and then press the arrow keys.
map-instructions.body-zooming: {zooming} To zoom in and out of the map, mouse scroll up and down while you mouse over the interactive map or click the {plus} and {minus} buttons respectively. Alternatively, {tab} focus to the interactive map box and then press the {plus} or {minus} keys. To zoom out to the maximum map extent, press the "zoom to globe" button.
map-instructions.label: How to Use: Interactive Map

old-search.body: You have made changes in the search form that do not match with the current search results displayed. Please press the {search} button to update the search results.
old-search.title: Outdated Search Results

table-instructions.body-filtering: {filtering} To filter the table, type in the search bars at the top of each column or the "search all" bar.
table-instructions.body-paging: {paging} Change the "show entries" dropdown to change how many stations are displayed on the page. Click "next" or "previous" to show additional pages of the table.
table-instructions.body-sorting: {sorting} To sort the table, click on the arrow symbols next to the column headings.
table-instructions.label: How to Use: Interactive Table

common.woudcFull: World Ozone and Ultraviolet Radiation Data Centre

blurb.body-alternatives: If you have difficulty with the following form, you can use any of our {contact-channels} to contact us.
blurb.body-contact: If you do not find answers to your questions or to submit your comments, suggestions, and ideas about {woudc}, we can respond to your inquiries through the service channels below.
blurb.body-faq: For answers to technical questions, please consult the {faq} section.

contact.name: Name

note.body: All personal information created, held or collected by this department is protected under the {privacy-act}. This means that you will be informed of the purpose for which it is being collected and how to exercise your right of access to that information. You will be asked for your consent where appropriate.
note.title: Personal Information Collection Statement

contact.prompt: Please provide information that we could use to contact you.
contact.subject: Subject
contact.title: Contact WOUDC
contact.description: Contact information for WOUDC related inquiries

list.blurb: The contributor list provides the institute or organization name and abbreviation, address, contact information and local file information.
list.title: Contributor List
list.description: List of contributors, including the institute or organization name and abbreviation, address, contact information and local file information.

blurb.body-accounts: All new data contributors require a WOUDC account. All account applications are subject to review by the WOUDC personnel. WOUDC reserves the right to evaluate all applications for data submission for compliance with the World Meteorological Organization (WMO) Global Atmosphere Watch (GAW) data exchange protocols.
blurb.body-submissions: Contributors of new data are asked to follow the steps below for arranging {submissions} to WOUDC for ozone and/or ultraviolet radiation data sets:

registration.step2: Obtain a GAW ID (required) for each station by registering with {wmo-gaw} ({more});
registration.step3: Complete the WOUDC registration process by {contacting} with the subject line: {register} and include your new GAW ID; and
registration.step4: Upon receipt and approval of your registration, the WOUDC will assign an FTP location / account (with a personal username/password) to be used exclusively for data submission.
registration.thanks: Thank you for registering with WOUDC.
registration.title: Registration
registration.description: List of steps required to register with WOUDC and to edit existing data if already registered.

submission.blurb-contact: It is recommended that data be submitted at least once a month. Please {contact-us} for further information.
submission.blurb-intro: The WOUDC processes data on a daily basis for near real-time data submissions. Registered contributors can submit data to the WOUDC via FTP.
submission.note1: files cannot be updated after they are transferred to the WOUDC. To submit updated data files, transfer again using a different file name.
submission.note2: step details may vary depending on your computer system and FTP software.
submission.step1: Data files can be sent individually or packaged into .zip, .tar, or .tar.gz format. See {formats} for more information
submission.step2: Using an FTP client, connect to the {ftp}
submission.step3: Log in with your pre-assigned username and password
submission.step4: Each contributor transfers their respective files to their individual folder on the FTP site (files cannot be updated after transfer to WOUDC. To submit updated data files, they must be transferred again, using a different file name)
submission.step5: Log out to end the FTP session
submission.subtitle: Data Submission Steps
submission.title: Data Submission
submission.description: How to submit data to WOUDC

validation.blurb: This process performs syntax and format checks against a file in support of realtime format validation of ozone and ultraviolet radiation data submissions to the Data Centre.
validation.no-results: No validation has been performed yet.

table-instructions.blurb: Drag and drop an extended CSV file into the text area below or click the browse button to upload one from your computer. Click the Validate button to validate your format. You can make edits in the text area or click Clear to clear the text area.
table-instructions.label: How to Use: Data Validator

validation.title: Data Validator
validation.description: Format checker and quality assessment for ozone and ultraviolet radiation data submission files.

single.keywords: contributor name, contributor agency, contributor abbreviation, contributor details, contributor country, contributor stations, contributor metadata
single.description: Description of a single contributor, including the contributor stations.

blurb.body-accessibility: Every effort has been made to make the WOUDC data archive as accessible as possible. If you have any questions, comments, or suggestions on improving data access, please {contact-us}.
blurb.body-intro: Access to the WOUDC data archive is available via numerous mechanisms in support of vendor neutral, multi-application access and integration. Whether you are using the website, geospatial tools or custom solutions, the WOUDC data archive provides flexible, authoritative data access.

csw.blurb: The {ogc-cs} provides a common interface to discover, browse and query discovery metadata (data about data). The WOUDC CSW provides a yellow pages catalogue of all WOUDC data available in the archive. Metadata records are formatted using the ISO 19115/19139 geospatial metadata standards.

note.body: WOUDC provides OGC CSW (version 2.0.2) at the following endpoint: {link}
note.title: WOUDC OGC CSW

csw.title: Catalogue Service for the Web (CSW)

definitions.blurb: Web Services are modelled and managed using a data taxonomy. An RDF-based definitions service exists to describe WOUDC's data taxonomy and relationships.

note.body: WOUDC provides RDF/SKOS at the following endpoint: {link}
note.title: WOUDC Definitions Service

definitions.title: Definitions Service

examples.blurb: The following {github} examples provide high level access and workflow examples of integrating WOUDC Web Services:

links.notebooks: {notebooks}: A collection of data centre workflows implemented as IPython notebooks
links.pywoudc: {pywoudc}: High level package providing Pythonic access to WMO WOUDC data services

examples.title: Examples

iso.blurb-howto: Please consult the {how-to} for detailed information.
iso.blurb-intro: Codelists are managed using the ISO 19115 standard. An ISO 19115 codelist catalogue exists to describe various WOUDC's domain objects for use in metadata.

note.body: WOUDC provides the ISO Codelist Catalogue at the following endpoint: {link}
note.title: WOUDC Codelist Catalogue

iso.title: ISO Codelist Catalogue

note1.body: All data and metadata are subject to the WOUDC {policy}.
note1.title: Data Policy

note2.body: The data revision dates are available on the {stations-page} for stations that have provided revised data.
note2.title: Data Revisions/Updates

blurb.body-howto: Please consult the {how-to} for detailed information.
blurb.body-intro: Observation data are made available via the {search} page, which allows users to browse and filter the entire archive in a responsive, interactive manner. All data provide a link to download data for offline use in a variety of formats.

search.note: Please note that dataset specific limits are put on bulk data download to maintain quality of service.
search.title: Data Search / Download

access.title: Data Access

blurb.body-files: Static dataset {summary} are also available on the WAF in CSV format with ZIP compression. These archive files are updated on a daily basis and provide users the option to download an entire dataset in CSV format.
blurb.body-howto: Please consult the {how-to} for detailed information.
blurb.body-intro: The entire archive of contributed data files in Extended CSV format is made available at {waf} for users to browse, download or integrate into their workflows.

In addition to traditional data access mechanisms, WOUDC has made the archive available using geospatial web services adhering to publically available international standards. Web services are systems designed to support machine to machine interaction over a network, and are typically utilized in a client/server computing environment made available through programmatic access, associated tools and applications.
blurb.body-standards: The WOUDC web services adhere to open standards ratified by the {ogc} (OGC), and the {iso} (ISO) which enable interoperability and thus make data easy to discover, access, visualize and integrate. OGC and ISO standards play an important role in {interoperability} as part of the {wis} and are supported by numerous off the shelf open source or commercial tools.

table.title: The following OGC web services are made available for standards-based, dynamic data access:

blurb.body-intro: The {wfs} provides a common interface to access geospatial data. Typical use of WFS includes custom query / raw access to geospatial features. The WOUDC WFS provides archive data in numerous formats, including Extended CSV, KML, CSV, GML, ESRI Shapefile, MapInfo, GeoJSON, and NetCDF.
blurb.body-limits: The WFS has a server side limit of a maximum of 200000 features to ensure quality of service and availability.

note.body: WOUDC provides OGC WFS (versions 1.0.0 - 1.1.0) at the following endpoint: {link}
note.title: WOUDC OGC WFS

wms.blurb: The {wms} provides a common interface to visualize geospatial data layers. Typical use of WMS includes simple visualization in web or desktop GIS applications via web friendly image formats such as PNG or JPEG.

note.body: WOUDC provides OGC WMS (versions 1.1.1 - 1.3.0) at the following endpoint: {link}
note.title: WOUDC OGC WMS

wms.title: Web Map Service (WMS)

wps.blurb: The {wps} provides a common interface to define rules, inputs, outputs for geospatial processing / calculations. Typical use of WPS includes custom processes (buffer, overlay). The WOUDC WPS provides a suite of tools used in support of validation of submissions to the Data Centre.

note.body: WOUDC provides OGC WPS (version 1.0.0) at the following endpoint: {link}
note.title: WOUDC OGC WPS

wps.title: Web Processing Service (WPS)

ogcapi.intro-api: In addition to traditional data access mechanisms, WOUDC has made the archive available using Web Application Programming Interfaces (APIs) and geospatial web services adhering to publically available international standards. Web APIs are designed to support machine to machine interaction over the Internet, and can be used in web, mobile or desktop applications and tools.
ogcapi.title: Web Services and APIs
ogcapi.intro-ogc: WOUDC APIs support open standards from the {ogc} (OGC) which facilitate interoperability and thus make ozone and UV data easy to discover, access, visualize and integrate. OGC standards play an important role in weather/climate/water data exchange as part of the WMO Information System and are supported by numerous off the shelf open source or commercial tools.
ogcapi.intro-endpoint: WOUDC provides a central OGC API at the following endpoint: {url}
ogcapi.intro-provides: The API provides discovery, access and visualization functionality to all WOUDC data and metadata, as well as providing processes for data validation and quality assessment.
ogcapi.intro-consult: Please consult the {webServicesHowTo} for detailed information.

access.description: Methods in to access WOUDC data archive via website, search, WAF, and web services

blurb.body-datasets: The WOUDC data archive can be searched by data category: there are six ozone data categories and three ultraviolet (UV) radiation data categories. The ozone datasets for total column ozone include total ozone and total ozone observations and the vertical ozone profile includes lidar, ozonesonde, Umkehr N-value and C-Umkehr. The UV datasets for UV irradiance include broadband, multiband and spectral.
blurb.body-howto: For more details on how to use this page, please view the {how-to} guide.
blurb.body-search: To search and download data, select the dataset and observation time period. Optionally, draw your map extent of interest and then hit search. All available data for that time period will be displayed.

old-search.body: You have made changes in the search form that do not match with the current search results displayed. Please press the {search} button to update the search results.
old-search.title: Outdated Search Results

info.blurb: The WOUDC data archive can provide high level information about each dataset. Select a dataset of interest to see its ISO discovery metadata and a contextual map of the stations.
info.subtitle: Dataset
info.title: Dataset Information:

instruments.blurb: The WOUDC data archive can be sorted by instrument. The instrument list includes the instrument type, name and model.
instruments.title: Instrument List
instruments.description: A list of instruments from the WOUDC data archive, including the instrument type, name and model.
instruments.keywords: WOUDC, instruments, list, model, type, number, search

policy.blurb: Use of the WOUDC data are governed by the {wmo-policy} and {gaw-policy}.

doi.blurb: WOUDC has registered {dois} for both Ozone and UV data. DOIs are persistent identifiers that allow research data to be accessible and citable. They make research data easier to access, reuse and verify, thereby making it easier to build on previous work, conduct new research and avoid duplicating already existing work.
doi.title: Digital Object Identifiers (DOI)

gaw.blurb: Use of data obtained from one of the WMO GAW World Data Centres (WDC) is subject to the following statement endorsed by the WMO Executive Council and the Commission for Atmospheric Sciences (EC/CAS) panel of experts working group on environmental pollution and atmospheric chemistry [WMO, 2001a].:

note.body: For scientific, educational and policy related use, access to these [GAW] data is unlimited and provided without charge. By their use you accept that an offer of co-authorship will be made through personal contact with the data providers or owners whenever substantial use is made of their data. In all cases, an acknowledgment must be made to the data providers or owners and to the data centre when these data are used within a publication.
note.title: WMO Policy Statement

gaw.title: Global Atmosphere Watch Data Use Policy

policy.gaw-policy: WMO Global Atmosphere Watch (GAW) data use policy

products.blurb: When publishing products extracted from WOUDC such as graphs, lists, maps or metadata you are expected to acknowledge the WOUDC, as the data and produce source, using the appropriate citation, as per the example provided.

note.body: Environment and Climate Change Canada, Toronto (n.d.). World Meteorological Organization-Global Atmosphere Watch Program (WMO-GAW)/World Ozone and Ultraviolet Radiation Data Centre (WOUDC). Retrieved October 24, 2013, from https://woudc.org.
note.title: Example (3): Citation for products originating from the WOUDC site

products.title: Publishing Products

publishing.blurb-citations: When publishing data retrieved from the WOUDC you are expected to acknowledge the contributors who author these data as the data source and the WOUDC, using the appropriate citation as per the example provided.
publishing.blurb-contributors: For a complete list of all contributors refer to the {contributors-page}.

note1.body: JMA, & NASA-WFF. World Meteorological Organization-Global Atmosphere Watch Program (WMO-GAW)/World Ozone and Ultraviolet Radiation Data Centre (WOUDC) [Data]. Retrieved October 24, 2013, from https://woudc.org. doi:10.14287/10000001
note1.title: Example (1): Citation for ozone data originating (contributed) from the Japan Meteorological Agency (JMA) and NASA (NASA-WFF) retrieved from the WOUDC site

Retrieved October 24, 2013, from https://woudc.org. A list of all contributors is available on the website. doi:10.14287/10000001

Retrieved October 24, 2013, from https://woudc.org. A list of all contributors is available on the website. doi:10.14287/10000002

blurb.body-intro: The WMO facilitates the free and unrestricted exchange of data and information, products and services in real or near-real time on matters relating to safety and security of society, economic welfare and the protection of the environment.
blurb.body-resolution40: {link} WMO policy and practice for the exchange of meteorological and related data and products including guidelines on the relationships in commercial meteorological activities.

policy.description: Data Use Policies, Protocols and Citation Guidelines

products.blurb: Special output data products are prepared by the WOUDC to assist researchers and provide value added information; some of the data products include total column ozone time series graphs and near real-time ozone maps.

maps.blurb: Near-real time, global total ozone maps, normally updated daily at approximately 1400 UTC.

ozone_maps.title: Ozone maps
ozone_maps.description: Search tool of ozone maps by observed or non-observed, forecast ozone type, total or deviation values or regions.
ozone_maps.keywords: ozone maps, observed ozone, forecasted ozone, individual sourced, combined sources, total ozone, deviation from normal, northern hemisphere, southern hemisphere, globe, global, Brewer, Dobson, TOMS, TOVS, GOME, KNMI, NCEP, SMOBA, TOAST
ozone_maps.day21ToEndMean: Day 21 to the end of the month
ozone_maps.numToDisplay: Number of past maps to display
ozone_maps.southernDesc: The most recent full-day total ozone map for the southern hemisphere
ozone_maps.northernDesc: The most recent full-day total ozone map for the northern hemisphere
ozone_maps.globalDesc: The most recent full-day total ozone map for the globe
ozone_maps.forecastOnThisDay: Forecasts for this day, prepared earlier
ozone_maps.forcastForThisDay: Forecasts prepared on this day, for future days
ozone_maps.sourcedObservedResults: Results of observed ozone maps from individual sources
ozone_maps.sourcedForecastResults: Results of forecast ozone maps from individual sources
ozone_maps.noaaSmoba: NOAA SMOBA (Stratosphere Monitoring Ozone Blended Analysis)
ozone_maps.mapsDescIntro: Maps of deviations represent total ozone deviations from the {level19781988} estimated using {tomsFullName} data for all areas except the Antarctic, and from the pre-1980 level estimated using Dobson data over the Antarctic.
ozone_maps.viewMapsIndividualSources: View ozone maps from the individual data sources (TOMS, SMOBA, TOVS and ground-based)
ozone_maps.mapsDescUpdateDaily: These maps are normally updated daily at about 1400 UTC. However, this near-real-time system is automated, so if a system problem occurs outside of regular working hours, it will not be fixed until the following work day.
ozone_maps.mapsDescNumbersDobsonUnits: The numbers on the high resolution maps indicate total ozone values in Dobson Units measured at ground-based stations. Small symbols after the numbers indicate type of observation: the most reliable direct sun measurements have no symbols, less reliable observations from zenith sky light are marked by âzâ. Focus moon observations during the polar night are marked by â+â symbol. All other types of measurements are marked by â*â. For more information on ground-based ozone measurements visit the WOUDC Web site.
ozone_maps.mapsDescWarningRealtime: The data are processed in near real-time, have not been fully validated, and are preliminary.
ozone_maps.aboutMeasurements: The total ozone maps are based on ground-based measurements available from the World Ozone and Ultraviolet Radiation Data Centre. Preliminary near real-time data from ground-based observations were also used for the most recent maps. Total ozone values are given in {dobsonUnits}. The numbers represent observations taken from ground stations situated at the bottom left corner of the number.
ozone_maps.aboutDeviations: Maps of deviations represent total ozone deviations from the {level19781988} estimated using {tomsFullName} data for all areas except the Antarctic and from the pre-1980 level estimated using Dobson data over the Antarctic.
ozone_maps.aboutPoorCoverage: Over areas with poor data coverage adjustments are made according to {toms} on Nimbus-7, Meteor-3, ADEOS and Earth Probe satellites. Over the polar night area Dobson and Brewer moon observations and/or NOAA's {tovsFullName} satellite data are used. TOVS data are also used when the more reliable TOMS data are not available. The mapping algorithm is similar to those used by the {wmoOzoneMappingCentre}.
ozone_maps.aboutDateInterval: The â@:data.products.ozone_maps.meanTypeâ can specify a day (1 to 31), a mean over the entire month (1-end) or the mean of a â10-dayâ period during the month (1-10, 11-20 or 21-end, which might be 8 or 9 or 11 days). It must logically correspond to the unit of the âInterval typeâ.

dd.allSourcesBlended: âAll sources blendedâ is a smaller copy of the total ozone maps found in the Ozone map archive. It is built from a blend of the other maps. Satellite data have been smoothed.
dd.groundBasedData: âGround-based dataâ are from instruments on the ground, Brewers, Dobsons, filter ozonometers, {saozInstruments}. New data are contributed by {eccc}, the {russianCentralAerologicalObservatory}, and by agencies in many other countries. Older data have been obtained from the World Ozone and Ultraviolet Radiation Data Centre (WOUDC). Data quality is best when taken on a sunny day, but techniques are available to measure ozone during cloudy days and sometimes at night using lunar light.
dd.toms: âTOMS satelliteâ is from {nasa}'s {tomsFullName} on board the Earth Probe satellite. Data from the OMI instrument are also included here.
dd.tovs: âTOVS satelliteâ is from {noaa}'s {tovsFullName} on the NOAA polar-orbiting satellites. Its data is less reliable than TOMS data but TOVS can see ozone at night, in particular during the polar night.
dd.gome: âGOME satelliteâ. For the period 1995-2003, data is from the {esaFullName}'s {gomeFullName} on board the {esa2FullName}. For the period from 2008, data is from the {gome2} instrument on board {metOpA} (launched in October 2006) provided by the {wdrsatFullName}.
dd.knmiAnalysis: âKNMI analysisâ is based on the {gomeFastDeliveryService} data (up to 2003), and data from the {sciamachy} instrument on the {envisat} satellite, interpreted by the {temis} service (starting 2004), provided by the {knmiFullName}.
dd.smoba: âSMOBA analysisâ is from {noaa}'s {smobaFullName}, which uses measurements from SBUV/2 (Solar backscatter ultraviolet instrument) equatorward of the polar night with TOVS ozone data blended from the terminator poleward.
dd.toast: âTOAST analysisâ is from {noaa}'s {toastFullName}, which uses measurements from SBUV/2 and TOVS.
dd.ncep: âNCEPâ forecasts are issued daily by the {ncepFullName} of the {noaaFullName} in the USA, for every 6 hours from 0 to 120, at 0h UTC each day. These maps are a subset, representing every 24 hours from 12 to 108, i.e. for 12h UTC on days 0 to 4.
dd.knmiForecasts: âKNMIâ forecasts are issued daily by the {knmiFullName}, representing every day from 0 to 4, at 12h UTC.
dd.totalOzone: âTotal Ozoneâ represents the total amount of ozone in a vertical column reaching from the earth's surface to the top of the atmosphere. Values are given in {dobsonUnits}.
dd.deviationFromNormal: âDeviation from Normalâ represents total ozone deviations from the {level19781988} estimated using TOMS data. Values are given in percent.

ozone_maps.wdcrsatFullName: World Data Center for Remote Sensing of the Atmosphere (WDC-RSAT)

dataSourcesFrom.omi: the {omiFullName}, a joint project of the {nivrFullName}, and the {fmiFullName} on board {nasa}'s {eos} {aura} satellite. OMI data are available from the {nasaTomsSite} and are processed with Version 8 of the TOMS processing algorithm
dataSourcesFrom.gome: the {gomeFullName} on the {esaFullName}'s {ers2} satellite and {gome2} on {eumetsat}'s {metOpA} satellite
dataSourcesFrom.toast: {noaa}'s {toast}, and from observations taken at ground-based stations by many national agencies.

ozone_maps.illustrationPurposes: These maps are for purposes of illustration only. For any more detailed use of the data, please go to the original sources mentioned above.
ozone_maps.toastFullName: Total Ozone Analysis using SBUV/2 and TOVS (TOAST)
ozone_maps.totalOzoneInDobsonUnits: Total ozone values are given in {dobsonUnits}.

ozone_maps.titleSouthern: Most recent total ozone maps for the southern hemisphere

josieBesos.title: JÃ¼lich Ozone Sonde Intercomparison Experiment (JOSIE) and Balloon Experiment on Standards for Ozone Sondes (BESOS) data
josieBesos.besosBlurb: In 2004 the WMO BESOS (Balloon Experiment on Standards for Ozonesondes) field campaign, carried out in Laramie (Wyoming, USA), deployed a large gondola with 18 ozonesondes and the OPM of WCCOS {attribution} with results similar to those of JOSIE.
josieBesos.josieBlurb: In order to assess the performance of various electrochemical ozonesondes and to guarantee consistency in ozonesonde data, the environmental simulation facility at the Forschungszentrum Juelich has been established in 1994 as the {wccosFullName} of WMO-GAW as part of their Quality Assurance (QA) plan. Beginning in 1996, a series of {josieFullName} campaigns has since been conducted at the WCCOS to evaluate different ozonesonde types {attribution}.
josieBesos.metaDescription: Dataset download links and abstract of the {josie}-{besos} data products (@:data.products.josieBesos.title).
josieBesos.wccosFullName: World Calibration Centre for Ozone Sondes (WCCOS)

normal-ozone-maps.title: Maps of normal ozone
normal-ozone-maps.description: These maps show the mean 1978-1988 level estimated using Total Ozone Mapping Spectrometer (TOMS) data for all areas except the Antarctic and from the pre-1980 level estimated using Dobson data over the Antarctic.
normal-ozone-maps.keywords: normal ozone maps, ozone maps, global, southen hemisphere, northern hemisphere, globle, Mean total ozone, total ozone, maps of normal ozone

captions.beginning: The mean total ozone for the

quality.blurb: The WOUDC data are subject to the Global Atmosphere Watch quality assurance system and the oversight of the Scientific Advisory Groups on ozone and solar ultraviolet radiation.

eccc.blurb: The WOUDC is operated by the Department of the Environment (referred to as Environment and Climate Change Canada) and undertakes the following activities:
eccc.item2: Checks submitted data for necessary format elements and the availability of comprehensive metadata and reject the submission of data that do not meet these formal criteria;
eccc.item3: Performs plausibility and consistency checks on submitted data, flag data problems, and provide feedback to the stations, when necessary;
eccc.item4: Provides collection of data user feedback;
eccc.item5: Shares results of quality assessment and user feedback with data contributors so that data can be corrected or corrective actions can be taken as required; and
eccc.title: Environment and Climate Change Canada

quality.gaw-blurb: The primary objectives of the {gaw-qa} are to ensure that the data in the World Data Centres are consistent, of known and adequate quality, supported by comprehensive metadata, and sufficiently complete to describe global atmospheric states with respect to spatial and temporal distribution.

blurb.body-intro: The SAG on ozone and solar ultraviolet radiation establish data quality objectives and {sop} outlining measurement methods and procedures.
blurb.body-standards: The SAG ensure that all data produced by the system conform to international standards, via the following calibration centres:

brewer.text: WMO GAW World Calibration Centre for Brewer total ozone measurements

dobson.text: WMO GAW World Calibration Centre for Dobson total ozone measurements

ozonesonde.text: WMO GAW World Calibration Centre for ozonesonde measurements

quality.title: Data Quality

stations.blurb: The WOUDC data archive can be sorted by station. To find out the identifying number of a particular station, select the metadata link on the WOUDC website and then the region that you are interested in. All available stations and their numbers for that region will then be displayed.
stations.title: Station List
stations.description: List of all stations from the WOUDC data archive
